Description: Fragment of a highly polished dark green stone (basalt or greywacke ?) figure, manufactured to represent the head to waist. Both arms and the left side are missing. The subject wears a hat with a tunic with incised circular motifs.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by The Petrie Museum of Egyptian Archaeology. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallel in Cairo Museum (not dated other than Greco-Roman) with same incised circles was said to be of steatite or dark schist (Edgar 1903, CG27503). It is a boy (wearing a pointed cap, often depicted representing people from the Nile Delta) on fish. Similar incised circles are a feature on bone and ivory objects of the Archaic period, and the hair is reminiscent of Egyptian representations of Africans (also on scarabs from Naukratis dating to the early 6th century BC) Edgar, C. C. 1903. Greek sculpture. Catalogue général des antiquités égyptiennes du Musée du Caire. Le Caire : Imprimerie de l'Institut français d'archéologie orientale
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (CE.220) (Phase 3)
